Adepti

Adepti are immortal illuminated beasts of Liyue, who have protected people for millennia. As humans have a higher purpose, only those of non-human status can be Adepti. No one is born an Adeptus, and no one remains an Adeptus forever, so all of non-human status can become an Adeptus. The word "Adeptus" is merely a title, so not all illuminated beasts are referred to as such. The Adepti are known as the "mighty and illuminated" Adepti, and this "illumination" refers to the light of a third "eye" that they possess, which allows them to use elemental powers without A Vision. For humans, the third "eye" takes the form of a Vision, but Adepti, pure elemental beings, are closer to the origin of ultimate truth than ordinary mortals. They were born amongst the elemental energy that courses between heaven and earth, so channeling elemental power is something that can be done almost subconsciously. They do not require the aid of an external focus to do so, let alone a Vision. It is not known for certain how Adepti get their Visions, however, when they take the human form, they tend to use a Vision to follow human rules.

Half-Adepti, who have a mixture of human and illuminated beast blood flowing through their veins, likely can't change their form and have an appearance of both illuminated beasts and humans (Ganyu has horns and Yanfei has antlers and scales). Their life expectancy is much longer than ordinary people because some half-Adepti live for more than 3000 years. Although half-Adepti have a natural ability to resonate with the world, they receive Visions like mortal people, which help them to enhance their powers.

Rex Lapis, the Geo Archon, is the Prime of Adepti, who can bless other Adepti as part of their "illumination." One such blessing is the ability to create small, autonomous pocket worlds and Adepti's abodes. Although Adepti of the north, Fujin and Herblord, were worshiped as Adepti, they don't have an Adeptal name and don't have some of the southern Adepti powers, like the ability to create abodes. Each Adeptus has their own powers. Thus, Rex Lapis and Menogias could control the Geo element, Xiao and Cloud Retainer could control the Anemo element, Indarias could control Pyro, and Bonanus and Bosacius could control Hydro and Electro powers respectively. Adepti can use their powers even to save humans from death, although mortals can't bear such energy.
When Adepti die, there's a tradition of "sending Adepti off," which is called the Rite of Parting and allows Adepti to ascend. This Rite is a ceremony, that requires special costumes, a special time, place, weather, and the audience. Some people believe that Adepti ascended to Celestia or were even born there, but no one really knows the truth of their birth and death.

Many Adepti live in Jueyun Karst, which is considered the realm of the Adepti of Liyue, usually unreachable by mortals. However, there are special "Herb Gatherers" who make their living by collecting valuable natural resources found only in Jueyun Karst. Other mortals need the special Sigil of Permission to enter the sacred lands. Some Adepti make traps for careless travelers and Treasure Hoarders, so no one will disturb them.

customize.text: Archon War

Long before the Archon War, when Rex Lapis had not yet received a Gnosis, he, along with other Gods and Adepti, founded Liyue and Guili Assembly. Guizhong, the God of Dust, imparted her wisdom along with her skill to craft machinery onto humanity. Marchosius, the Stove God, gave people the knowledge of cooking and creating ovens. Together with other Adepti, they defended their people. In those distant times, Adepti of the south, who served Rex Lapis, were friends with Adepti of the north, who served another Goddess. Adepti often had tea parties, spent their time together, played music, and sang.

When the Archon War began, Liyue's lands became a battlefield. The Goddess of the north and her servants, Fujin and Herblord, fought with Rex Lapis; the Guili Plains were flooded, and the Adepti helped the inhabitants to move to Liyue Harbor, which later became the main city. Many Adepti were killed in this war. Marchosius sacrificed himself for the people, losing his powers and memory and turning into Guoba. Skybracer sacrificed his antlers to support a collapsing mountain, ensuring the safety of villagers, and kept on fighting until his blood was drained, and his life ran out. Herblord and Fujin went against their Goddess to protect people and lost all their Adeptal energy. 3700 years ago, Adepti entered into a contract with Rex Lapis and promised to protect Liyue Harbor.

After the Archon War, the lands of Liyue were plagued by pestilence and famine. The rotting remains of the defeated gods spread across the world, reborn into demons. The monsters' rage manifested in the form of diseases, monster infestations, and other strange occurrences. Then, Rex Lapis summoned the Yakshas to vanquish the demons. They swore an oath: <color=#ffffffd9>"Restore order through slaughter, purge evil through battle. To this, we dedicate our lives."</color> Being the most fierce and warlike of all the Adepti, they were ready to do anything to protect the lands.
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.text: Death of Rex Lapis

When Rex Lapis was killed during the Rite of Descension, Adepti were furious at the people of Liyue. Cloud Retainer wanted to destroy the entire Liyue Harbor. She believed that after the death of the Archon, terrible events would follow, from which she wanted to free people. Adepti believed that Liyue Qixing, who ruled Liyue, failed in their task and allowed the death of the Archon.
Once Rex Lapis came to them in a dream, the Adepti decided to temporarily reconcile with Liyue Qixing to protect people from the threat. Osial, Overlord of the Vortex was defeated by Rex Lapis during the Archon War, and then summoned by the Fatui Harbinger, Childe, in hopes of luring out Rex Lapis and obtaining his Gnosis for Tsaritsa. Adepti modified the Guizhong Ballista to turn it into an engine of war, and through the joint efforts of the Milleliths, Liyue Qixing, and Adepti, the ancient god was stopped, and Liyue was saved.
After this battle, the Adepti completely entrusted the reign to Liyue Qixing. When Osial's wife, Beisht, wanted to attack Liyue again to avenge her husband, they no longer interfered and allowed the people to defend the city themselves.
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Gnosis
customize.desc: Gnoses are internal magical foci that each of The Seven possesses, allowing them to resonate directly with Celestia itself and serving as an emblem of their status. The Gnoses were created from the remains of the Third Descender.

customize.name: Cloud Retainer

customize.name: Childe
customize.desc:
"Childe" Tartaglia, Eleventh of the Fatui Harbingers.
He draws power from the ominous Delusion he possesses and fights using martial arts that he learned in a land of darkness.

He is a pure warrior with an insatiable lust for battle.
Each bloody conflict, each life-and-death struggle is a delightful trial to him.
People say that the young Childe is famed throughout the land for his battle prowess.
But he has never taken big talk of this kind to heart.

After all...
"You shall ever be the eye of the storm,
"And the clashing of steel shall ever accompany you.
"The pitch-black memory of stepping into uttermost darkness,
"Shall, at last, become the strength by which you will overturn this world."

customize.text: Celebrations

During the Archon War, the people of Liyue illuminated the night sky with lanterns to serve as a reminder of the way home to their warriors and to never lose sight of themselves. Lantern Rite is an annual festivity to honor these heroes. Fallen Adepti are commemorated during the Lantern Rite in the form of the Mingxiao Lantern — a giant lantern with a Plaustrite as the central stone in them. During the festivals that the Traveler and Paimon attended, Skybracer, Sea Gazer, and Menogias were commemorated.

Legend has it that while some Adepti were pursuing the Adeptal path, they would wander across mountains and rivers, enjoying various gourmet dishes, using such means to quiet their hearts. Their path would be called the "Trail of Delicacies" by those who came after. Moonchase originally served as a rite exclusive to the Adepti, but now Moonchase Festival is a celebration of the arrival of the fall by moonlight, when people eat their favorite foods, spend time with friends and relatives, and enjoy the moon and the flowers.
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Lantern Rite
customize.desc: Every year on the day of the first full moon, Liyue celebrates the Lantern Rite. At night, the people launch many Xiao Lanterns and one large Mingxiao Lantern into the sky. Inside each lantern is a piece of plaustrite and the heart's desires written on special sticks. The lanterns slowly float away, illuminating the way for the souls of Liyue's faithful defenders.

customize.name: Moonchase Festival
customize.desc: The Moonchase Festival celebrates the arrival of the fall by moonlight.

customize.text: Eight Adepts

During the Archon War, there was a divine mountain in Liyue with a giant tree on its summit. This tree was a god named "Tao Dou," originally known as "Bune." Back then, people thought that behind Tao Dou was the realm of the dead, and if you committed grave sins in life, your soul would be unable to pass beyond that tree and into the afterlife. About two to three thousand years ago, the Eight Adepts rose up — eight people and beasts who laid down a great magic array to purify Tao Dou. He cared greatly for all living things and volunteered to sanctify himself to pacify the underworld. Without the god's will, not even eight Adepti would have been able to overpower him, much less the Eight Adepts. Tao Dou was sealed in a secret palace in the Qingce Mountains called the "Hidden Palace of Zhou Formula" along with other evil spirits, and the palace itself was enchanted using the Seven-Eight Gates method. After that, Tao Dou's remains sank into the Ley Lines and became a border, separating the living of Liyue from the dead in Liyue. The mortals continued to preserve and maintain the god's new form for thousands of years.

Among the Eight Adepts, there were three joined forces: the Three Hermits of Guizang, the Two Sages of Lianshan, and the Three Beasts of Tao Dou. Although they possessed powers comparable to those of the Adepti, many of them were ordinary mortals. One of the hermits was called "Wind Reader," he came from the Twelve Tribes of the Chenyu Vale, and his descendants became the founders of the Lan clan and the ancient art of Qimen Divination. The second hermit mastered the art of fishing with a rod and line, and became known to the people as the "Yunlai Angler." It is believed that Yunlai Swordsmanship, which Yuheng of the Liyue Qixing, Keqing, uses, was based on Yunlai Angler's rod-wielding techniques. The third hermit was the Wuwang Kid, also known as Old Man Wuwang. According to legend, he always presented himself in child form and was a master of Qihuang sigils, which he used to catch demons, heal disease, and protect lives from the encroaching presence of death. The Lianshan Sages included Sage Hu, a master of gourd crafts, and Sage Jian, an expert in bronze mirrors. Little is known about them, but they were known to have mastered the secret art of Lianshan, earning them the title of the Two Sages of Lianshan. A hidden palace is located deep in the mountains south of the Stone Gate. It is believed to be where they retreated for cultivation. The Three Beasts of Tao Dou, also known as the Three Immortals of Tao Dou, lived on the mountain where the divine tree grew. They were known as the Lone Butterfly of the Crimson Flame, the Jade-Plumed
and the Gold-Eyed Celadon Mare. These were three auspicious beasts, all with the power to take on human form similar to those of the Adepti. During Tao Dou's purification ceremony, the Lone Butterfly sacrificed herself, Silverwing and Wind Reader traveled together, and the white horse went to live in seclusion in the Qingce mountain range. Although they all had remarkable powers, purifying a god of Tao Dou's caliber was no mean feat. They had to use the secret art of Seven-and-Eight-Gates Array, which involved obfuscating one of the gates so that evil couldn't escape. The Lone Butterfly was in charge of the hidden gate that was chosen to be obfuscated, and so she disappeared from the world in the process. According to legend, Old Man Wuwang looked up to her a lot, took up her mantle, and kept her legacy alive, passing it on to the founders of the Wangsheng Funeral Parlor. Thus, the Butterfly sacrificed her life to restore order to the realm of the dead, some chance meetings ensured that future generations continued using her methods to guard the border between life and death. Although she herself disappeared from the world, her mission to protect Liyue is still alive and well, thousands of years on.
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Archon War
customize.desc: The war for the divine thrones, declared by the Heavenly Principles. As a result of the Archon War that finished about 2000 years ago, seven rulers of seven nations received the Gnoses, the divine throne, and the title of an Archon.

customize.text: Legends

There are many legends about Adepti. The first legend is about stone statues that appear all across the vast land of Liyue. Legend has it that in some corners of the land, ancient stone beasts wake at night in the cool of the fall and look around at a world that has slowly become alien to them. Hearing the sounds of frogs and insects greeting them, they respond with deep, soulful cries from their petrified throats. Then they roam around Liyue, inspecting once more the land they used to protect. The elders of Qingce Village say that these statues are illuminated beasts who once fought alongside Rex Lapis in the Archon War. After the war ended, the tide subsided, and peace was restored. The illuminated beasts were no longer required to serve as defenders of the common people, and one by one they retreated to more secluded parts of the country. There they lived free from concern for mortal affairs. But some illuminated beasts remembered with fondness the glorious days when they served under Rex Lapis, and they pined for the years they protected Liyue. Though they were not of the mortal realm, nor were they immortal: For them, too, life would one day come to an end. Thus, they beseeched Rex Lapis to turn their ephemeral flesh bodies into everlasting stone. The merciful Geo Archon granted their request and made them as such.
The second legend tells a story about Qilin, a type of noble, gentle, and benevolent illuminated beast. Qilin often roam the mountain forests but appear only on nights when starlight shines upon clear dew. For sustenance, they drink only spring water and eat only fragrant herbs. It is said that Qilin will never harm living things, refusing even to step on an insect or break a blade of grass. People believe that a Qilin's characteristics, behavior, and their every movement is dictated by an age-old etiquette that has remained unchanged for a thousand years. Legend has it that several thousand years ago, a herb gatherer was bathing in a mountain pool when to his surprise, a passing Qilin began to eat the clothes that he had left by the water's edge. The illuminated beast was too young to understand human notions of shame and privacy and had yet to learn the conduct of illuminated beasts in the mortal realm. To make up for her crude behavior and to avoid startling the vulnerable mortal with her otherworldly Adeptal appearance, she transformed into one of human bearing. As the pale light of the full moon fell onto the pool, she appeared before the herb gatherer. Together, they started a journey among flowers and bamboo groves, Qilin interpreted for the mortal the language of the birds, revealed to him the mountain dwelling of the Adepti, and they shared dreams. As the herb gatherer began to stir at the first light of dawn, he awoke to find that the noble illuminated beast had vanished without a trace. Some people say that the Qilin lived together with the mortal, gave birth to children, and grew accustomed to human life.
The third legend is about the boy and the horse-Adeptus, the Gold-Eyed Celadon Mare from the Eight Adepts. The boy got lost in the bamboo forest, and a slender woman with golden eyes and hair ever white-gold garbed in white offered to help drive him out of the forest. The mountain people once viewed her as time's daughter, like a white horse leaping from a pure spring, one whom no shackles could bind. Just as it was with her proud mother, so it was with her — no wall or eggshell could bar her path. The shepherds of the plains once pursued her steps, freeing themselves from the fetters of the wilderness, embarking on a migratory search for the waterweeds, and thus did the golden-white foal blaze the trail for all herds in the land. The kingdom of the ocean depths once saw her as an emissary, and based on their imagination, they granted her scales and tail plumage, falling down in worship of the light brought by one who was both mother and daughter. Before the war with the second throne, when the heavenly envoys favored the people, great heroes, and wandering champions would visit the clear springs for her blessing, fighting over the tenderness she left in her hurried wake. While the boy and Adeptus were spending the night in the woods, she told different stories about the three Moons and the times before the Archons were born.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Long ago, three bright moons once hung high in the night sky. These three moons were sisters, their years numbering more than those of the Geo Archon and their year of birth predating the very bedrock upon which Liyue Harbor now rests.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>The moons were daughters of prose and song, sovereign over the night sky. They navigated the heavens above in their silver carriage, alternating with one another thrice a month. If the reign was not promptly passed from one sister to the next, a terrible disaster would occur that very day.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>These three luminous moons shared but one love, the stars of daybreak. Only at the fleeting moments when day and night converged could one of the three sisters pass the fading stars and gaze upon the chambers of the morning stars. Moments later, as the new dawn would break over the horizon, the carriage would quickly ferry the night's sister away.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>The three sisters shared an equal affection for their one and only love, much like the affection they shared for one another. But this was all before the world was smashed against the tides of great calamity.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>With time, disasters overturned the sovereign carriage and laid ruin to the halls of the stars. The three sisters of the night turned against one another, leading to their eternal parting by death. Only one of their pale corpses now remains, ever shedding its cold light..."</color>

After the moon palace collapsed, the chariot fell, and the three sisters were slain, these legends became lost alongside disaster's descent, the heavens rained down cruel order, and from that day, the stars stilled their orbits, and the earth ceased to turn. As for the Adeptus, she had no choice but to be trapped within the shell of the starry sky, forced to tarry within this stagnant, foreign land, awaiting her mother's thousand threads, awaiting the erosion of hardy stone, awaiting the next encounter from beyond.
At dawn, the boy and Adeptus went their separate ways: the boy packed his things and headed for that thriving port city, while she stood silently at the boundaries of the bamboo forest. In the dawn's glow, he heard a whinnying cry that then grew distant. He turned and looked, and there was nothing behind him, but a single strand of hair that had come to rest on his shoulder. Many years later, the boy, who was a boy no longer, would remember that moment, and he would understand: the gap between them was like a yawning chasm. His fate was to leave his home and go to Liyue Harbor, to seek the riches the Geo Archon had bestowed upon him. Hers, then, was to hide herself away, away from the majestic, kindly gaze of that great Lord of Geo, and protect those ancient tales that even she was beginning to forget.

Another legend is about a martial nomad, Guhua. He was the master of the Rainslasher, a dimly fluorescent greatsword with no sharp edge. Years ago, it was known as the "Beacon of the Nether" by the mountain bandits, because seeing it meant there was no way back. Legend has it that Guhua was an Adeptus. While he lived, bandits dared not act and the wilderness knew a peace like that of the city. At the end of his journey, Guhua ascended to the heavens in a purple haze and became a star. One to whom Guhua had shown kindness founded what is now known as the Guhua School in his honor. Once, the Guhua Clan was well-known, but now it's a dying art that has been in constant decline for several hundred years.

One more legend is a local legend in Fontaine. Many generations ago, a traveler from Fontaine wandering through Liyue slipped and fell into a lake. As he sank and gasped for breath, he heard a wondrous tune in the air. They say it was the most beautiful, moving melody he had ever heard. Even in that life-and-death moment, the ethereal music seized his full attention and almost made him forget the fact that he was drowning. When he finally came to, he found that he had already been brought ashore. Not too far from him stood an unfamiliar woman with an almost divine aura. Once she saw that he was no longer in danger, she left without a word. The traveler tried to run after her to show his gratitude. Although a mere dozen paces separated them, no matter how quickly he gave chase, he drew no closer and remained a dozen paces behind. In the end, all he could do was bow in thanks to the woman as he watched her walk away towards the rivers and mountains in the distance before he turned around and made his way home. Once he returned to Fontaine, he began to learn an instrument to spread his story far and wide, just like the bards. After generations of retelling, embellishing, and dramatizing, people have come to think of that lady as something like a fairy. The story's become something of a local legend in Fontaine. It's called "The Lady Overlooking the Lake." People now say that if you go down to the lakeside and play an instrument, so long as you play a pleasing melody, you will hear a fairy lady, who is hiding out of sight, playing along with you.
The sixth legend is about a complex, famous dish in Liyue cuisine, Adeptus' Temptation. Specially selected ingredients are submerged and slowly bowled into soup stock. It is believed that the recipe scribbled from memory alone was enough to urge the Adepti to once again return to the world of men.
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Chenyu Vale
customize.desc:
The gentle breezes carry the fragrance of tea all across the mountains of Liyue, filling the air with the savory scent once more.

"Tea grows upon the rocks, where jade springs endlessly flow." The faint perfume and ancient song of jade drift together along the rivers past Qiaoying Village to the bustling port of Yilong Wharf. Just what adventures and fortune await, concealed among the fog-robed peaks of the south...?

customize.desc: Yaoyao and Xiangling's Master. She's an Adeptus, known as Streetward Rambler.

customize.name: Rainslasher
customize.desc: A fluorescent greatsword with no sharp edge that crushes enemies with brute force and raw power.

customize.name: Adeptus' Temptation
customize.desc: A complex, famous type of Liyue cuisine, in which specially selected ingredients are submerged and slowly boiled in soup stock. The recipe scribbled from memory alone was enough to urge the adepti to once again return to the world of men.
